ROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Kenova LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and the community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per Marathon policy. The Kenova Terminal is also evaluating the process emergency back-up power capabilities.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

The MPLX- Kenova LP Terminal is an on-shore, bulk petroleum terminal used in the storage and distribution of refined petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Kenova, WV. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum-based additives.

Kenova LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment (HES) goes hand-in-hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention/mitigation and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances.
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs.
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated substances.
D. An overview of the emergency response program.
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The butane blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program Level 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. Further, the Kenova LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, a Facility Response Plan (SMARTPLAN) is in place for the Facility with response activities being coordinated with Kenova and Ceredo Fire Departments/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Kenova LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all incidental (including near misses) and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated, follow-up actions. This is an existing Butane Blending process with additional storage capacity anticipated for 2024.  There have been no reportable (as defined in the EPA RMP regulations) accidents within the past five (5) years.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Kenova and Ceredo Fire Departments, the Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue and the Cabell/Wayne County LEPC. A Facility Response Plan (SMARTPLAN) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

The Facility (Non-Responding Stationary Source) maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire and 1st Responder Operations capability.

The Kenova and Ceredo Fire Departments/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue and LEPC participate in annual butane coordination/training and notification sessions for this process.

Addition exercises including Tabletop and/or Full-Scale are performed as agreed upon between responding agencies and the Facility.
